subject: Re: [junit] varying amount of time calculated using JUNIT 3.8 as well as 4.1
msgSnippet: Shubha, There is always variation in running times--however, it is possible that JUnit imposes a small amount of overhead compared to your very simple main
messageBody:
Shubha,

There is always variation in running times--however, it is possible
that JUnit imposes a small amount of overhead compared to your very
simple main function. What are you hoping to test for?

David Saff

On 3/14/07, Shubha B S <mailtoshubha@...> wrote:
> Colin,
>
> this variations happens only when I use JUnit. I have tried another sample like this..
>
> class simple{
> public static void main(String args[]) throws InterruptedException {
> long token = System.currentTimeMillis();
> Thread.sleep(2000);
> System.out.println(" time taken:" + (System.currentTimeMillis() - token));
>
> }
> }
>
> It always gives me constant value. Why this natural variation is not happening in this case and happens only when I use JUnit?
>
> thanks
> Shubha
> ----- Original Message ----

> Shubha,
>
> You're just experiencing natural variations in processing time, which
> will be caused by your CPU doing something else while you're app is
> running. This could be the Java GC running, OS paging to disk or just
> another application taking up some of the CPU. Short of having a true
> real-time system you're always going to see this.
>
